div.p:
Ex quoniam demonstratum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 37, c. 1, [n. 1]
, etc. This is distinction 37 in which, after the Master treated how things are in the divine science, now he shows how God is in the essence of every creature. And this is divided in three because in the first place regarding the being of God in things he lists some modes and approves of the true modes, in the second place he disproves false modes, in third place he confirms manifest what he says. The second begins at
cumque divina natura
Lombardus, Sent., I, d .37, c. 5, [n. 1]
. The third begins at
fateamur itaque
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 37, c. 9, [n. 1]
.

Regarding the first, he does two things because in the first place he shows how God is in some things in a special way through grace, in the second place how he is in some things generally through nature. The second begins at
ex praedictis patet
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 37, c. 3, [n. 5]
. The first part is divided into two parts because in the first place he shows that God dwells in holy men, in the second place he responds to some doubts. The second begins at
ex praedictis patet si autem quaeris
Lombardus, Sent. d. 37, c. 3, XXX
, etc.

The following question is asked, whether the divine or necessary principle in every being is a necessary being; whether just as God is the true and infallible idea of everything, so also every thing is locus of the capacity of God himself, though changeable?

That not because it would follow that God would not be able in some situations to act at a distance. The consequent is false because then an agent acts more quickly on something near at hand than something further removed. With the supposed disposition the consequence is clear, if God is everywhere, it follows no thing is locally at a distance from God. This is confirmed because it is the case that God is everywhere according to power and not according to essence, therefore.

In the second place, God is able to acquire a certain place, therefore God is not fixed in every place. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear both because God is able to be in a place or in a creature in which he is not, and also because it is possible that some being is not the locus of God because no created being is a necessary being.

In the third place, God is not present everywhere, therefore. The antecedent is clear in the first place God is able to begin to be anywhere, for having supposed that were to destroy every created place and then afterward were to recreate it, then in this case he would begin to be everywhere. Secondly because is not an inspiration or an empty imagined thing. Thirdly because the God-man is not everywhere, therefore God is not everywhere. The consequence holds because every God-man is man, and the antecedent is proved because God is not everywhere man, otherwise some body would de facto be in an infinity of places.

In opposition is the
Master in this distinction
XXX
. And this is confirmed because to be everywhere is a type of perfection, therefore it should be attributed to God. The consequence is clear. The antecedent is seen in the Master in the text.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
First conclusion: it is not the case that God is in a created thing through his own power that he himself is not in the same thing through is own essence. This is proved through the
Master, in this distinction 37, chapter 2 , saying
God is in all things and is always everywhere because to be everywhere proper to the deity.
Lombardus, XXX . Nevertheless note that according to
Giles, in his treatise on the body of Christ, theorem 5 , he says,
though it belongs to the deity to be in every place, nevertheless he is not determined to a place nor defined or circumscribed in a place
Aegidius Romanus, xxx . The same thing is said by the
Master
XXX .

First corollary: that if the divine power is not apart from any being or place, then it is sufficiently inferred that the essence is everywhere, contra
Scotus, in this distinction
Scotus, I, d. xxx . This is clear because the divine essence and power are the same.

Second corollary: though a created agent is able to act in some space
removed from itself by a certain distance, nevertheless the uncreated agent is not able to act or produce something through its omnipotence in any space or distance removed from itself The first part is clear from the illuminating sun given that there are parts of air distant from it and it produces heat in these parts. The second part is proved because is intimately present to every being and position, since this is proper to him
according to the Master
Lombardus, I, d. xxx .

Third corollary: though de facto to be present in every location attinctive does not properly belong to any created thing, nevertheless some created mutable things is able to be in every place contentive. The first is clear because to be everywhere attinctive through power and essence is proper to the deity alone, therefore. The second part is proved because let it stand that every created place other than the one in which I currently am be annihilated, in such a case it follows that I am everywhere and in every place.

The second conclusion: just as God does not lack his being in any created place, so God contains no place determinately. This is proved because to lack place is the proper disposition or condition of that which has been placed, therefore God is not properly contained in any place nor is he locatable. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear. The second part is proved because to be properly contained in space is to be terminated and exceeded by some space. But no place terminates or is able to exceed God, therefore.

The first corollary: though place, time, and situation are affirmed or said about God in a translated sort of way, nevertheless the modes by which God is in creatures are in someways distinguished The first is clear from
Augustine, V De Trinitate, chapter 8 , when he says,
but to be situated and had in space and in time are not properly, but translatively and through likenesses, said about God
Augustinus, De Trinitate, V, 8, 9
. The second part is proved through
Gerard of Siena, in the first book, in distinction 37, in article 2
Gerardus de Senis, Sent. I, d. 37, a. 2
because to be in according to essence is nothing other than to attain this other according to its essence such that between the essence of one and the essence of the other no intervening mediating distance occurs between these essence. And this leads back to the
second corollary of the first conclusion
, but to be according to presence is to attain something according to knowledge and foreknowledge, but to be in something according to power is to be in some mode according to a conserving operation.

The second corollary: it is as repugnant to God to be defined, moved, or changed in place as it is that there is some created being and that God is not intimately present with it. This is clear because according to
Augustine, V De Trinitate, chapter 3 , he says,
no things would be changeably good unless there were something unchangeably good.
Augustine, De Trinitate, VIII, 3, 5
. This is confirmed because to be defined or circumscribed in place is to terminate in place or to exceed something that has been placed.

Third corollary: it stands that God is in one mode only unchangeable in himself and that he is changeable in creatures in many or multiple modes. This is clear because God in diverse created things produces diverse and multiple effects, therefore. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because he produces one effect in a rational creature and another in a brute creature. The consequence is clear because that God is in creatures connotes an effect of God in these things. For this conclusion and corollaries see
Alanus in De maximis theologiae, regula 38
Alanus de Insulis, De Maximis Theologiae, rule 38
, where he says a collection of the creator to creatures according to which the creature is in the creatures as if an efficient cause in its effects, where it is said in a comment, for when it is said that God is everywhere, this is not thus said as if it is understood that he is circumscribed in a place but rather is a way of indicating the immensity of God and that all things are contained within his immensity rather than that he is understood to be in places.
Again in rule 39
Alanus de Insulis, De Maximis Theologiae, regula 39
, when spatial statements are predicated of God either the divine immensity or the gathering of grace or the union is understood. Where a concept indicates, when God is every place, here the divine immensity is predicated, when it is aid that God is in the saints the collection of divine grace is signified, for in the saints is said to be through grace, but when it is said in the assumed man, here is predicated the union, such that there is the sense that human nature is united in Christ. These says are the sayings found there.

Third conclusion: thought it is necessary that God is in any created thing, nevertheless God has being in a body or place contingently. The first part is clear because it does not the case that the created being exists and that God does not conserve it or that God is not intimately present to it. The second part is proved because one is able to annihilate this place, there God contingently has being in this place.

The first corollary: just as it is necessary that God is in anything which is, while it is, so God does not truly have being in anything that is not. The first part is clear through what has been said. The second part is proved because, if this were true, it would follow that this would be and not be. The consequent implies a contradiction. The consequence is clear because that God is in anything or in something this is attained through his essence, knowledge, and operation, as is clear through what has been said.

The second corollary: just it is not the case that place is and that God is apart from this place, so it is not the case that some place does not exist and that God is present there or that his being is in this place. The first part is clear because that God is in some place is something he attains through his operation, but he does not operate nor conserve non-being, therefore.

The second corollary: though God is necessarily everywhere or in some place, nevertheless God is not beyond the heavens in an imaginary vacuum. This is clear from the preceding corollary. This is confirmed because is not in that which pure nothingness, but a vacuum is precisely this type of thing, otherwise it would not be a vacuum, therefore.

The third corollary: just it is the case that ceases to be everywhere, so it is not repugnant for God to be everywhere. This is clear because God is able to destroy every place and every created thing and to create it again, by which having been posited the proposed follows. From which it is clear that God or the first necessity is often able to be everywhere. This is clear because from eternity God was not everywhere, therefore. The consequence is clear because just as God began to be everywhere through creation, so he is able to annihilate everywhere and create it again.

With respect to the corollary, just as the fact that God is often everywhere does not imply he is composed or composable, so that God moves from place to place, from time to time, does not imply that he varies. This is clear because the same ratio applies in both cases. For this the affirmative part of the conclusion follows.

Contra primam conclusionem, arguitur quia Deus potest aliquid producere extra caelum, ergo est ibi per potentiam. Sed non est ibidem per essentiam, ergo stat Deum esse alicubi per potentiam et non per essentiam.
Contra secundum corollarium, sequeretur quod Deus esset minoris perfectionis quam agens creatum probo quia posse agere in distans perfectionis est.

Contra idem, voluntas divina potest velle aliquod distans a se, ergo potentia divina potest producere aliquod distans a se. Consequentia tenet quia voluntas et potentia sunt idem formaliter et antecedens patet.

Contra secundam conclusionem et corollaria, Deus potest esse in aliquo modo loco ubi prius non erat et potest etiam non esse ubi prius erat, ergo Deus est mobilis seu mutabilis. Patet consequentia, et antecedens probatur quia si b destruatur Deus ibi non est amplius, sic etiam si novus locus creatur Deus illi erit noviter praesens. Confirmatur quia, si Deus nunc destrueret ultimum caelum, Deus non esset ubi nunc est ultimum caelum, potest ergo non esse in loco ubi est. Item, si Deus causaret aliquod corpus extra caelum, Deus esset ibidem, et nunc non est ergo, sed statim posset hic dici quod hoc non erit per mutationem ipsius Dei, sed per mutationem corporis extra caelum noviter creati.

Contra hoc, arguitur quia moveri localiter est esse nunc alicubi et prius alibi et alibi, sed tale corpus cum prius nihil esset nec erat prius in aliquo loco nec advenit
noviter in illo loco extra caelum, ergo Deus est motus localiter ad illum locum determinate quod est propositum. Confirmatur quia, si Deus non sit ibi nisi per corpus ibi noviter creatum, sequitur quod corpus creatum prius est ibi naturaliter quam Deus. Consequens est falsum quia sequitur quod corpus posset ibi creari absque hoc quod Deus esset ibi quia naturaliter prius potest esse sine posteriori. Item, Deus prius est naturaliter est alicubi quam agat ibi.

Contra primam partem tertiae conclusionis et eius corollaria, arguitur, si Deus non est in spatio vacuo extra caelum et ibi possit esse sine potentiae novi corporis, sequitur quod Deus sit mutabilis et mobilis localiter. Consequens est falsum. Patet consequentia quia talis transitus de non esse ibi ad esse ibi non potest esse sine mutatione in Deo vel in alio, sed quod Deus sine nova potentiae, etc. Probatur quia in tali
spatio sapatio
imaginatio Deus potest ponere angelum cum corpore creato et potest adnihilare illud corpus conservando angelum sicut si Deus adnihilaret aerem in ista domo existentem nos hic conservando.

Secundo, ante mundi creationem Deus erat praesens alicui spatio imaginabili extra caelum, ergo. Antecedens probatur quia Deum agere in aliquo spatio creato praesupponit Deum ibi esse cum prius ibi Deus potuerit creare mundum quam creaverit. Similiter extra caelum ultimum potest creare alium mundum, ergo.

Tertio, Deus cognoscit distincte et intuitive spatium infinitum extra caelum, ergo est praesens tali spatio. Patet consequentia quia omne intellectum a Deo est actualiter praesens Deo nisi sit in potentia tantum, sed tale spatium de facto est extra caelum, ergo.

Quarto, per
Beatum Augustinum V De Civitate Dei, capitulo 5
u
Augustinus, De Civitate Dei V, 5
ubi contra quaerentes quare Deus cepit creare mundum in hoc tempore determinato cum prius per temporaliter infinita cessasset et per modum is instantiae respondet dicens quod eodem modo potest ab eis quaeri quare in hoc spatio mundi determinate creavit mundum cum extra mundum pateant circumquaque infinita spatia et subdit quod si ipsi dicant substantiam Dei esse absentem tantis locorum spatiis extra mundum et uno tantum tam exiguo loco in quo nunc mundus ex occupatam inconveniens et vaniloquium est. Haec Augustini , ex quibus sequi videtur propositum.

Quinto, ponatur quod a sit situs mundi et b situs imaginarius similis extra caelum distans ab ipso et moveat Deus mundum ab a ad b situans mundum in b, tunc quaeritur aut Deus prius fuit in b vel non. Si sic, habetur propositum. Si non, igitur eadem ratione Deus non est nunc in ipso a, ergo Deus recessit ab a et accessit ad b, ergo Deus localiter est motus, quod est falsum. Ergo sequitur quod sicut Deus nunc est in a sic prius in b situ.

Ad primam dividitur quod in proprie dicitur quod Deus potest agere in aliquo ubi extra caelum quia extra caelum non est aliquod ubi nec ibi vel locus. Secundo posset fieri differentia inter has species Deus potest agere ibi et Deus potest agere. Tertio, posset dici quod ubicumque Deus est potens agere ibi est praesentia divinae essentiae.

Ad secundam, negatur consequentia quia, licet in causis limitatis non posse agere indistans procedat ex imperfectione, tamen in causa illimitata ex perfectione procedit, scilicet ex immensitate et simplicitate et immobilitate divina.

Ad tertiam, dicitur quod divina voluntas non potest velle aliquod distans a se propter eius immensitatem et simplicitatem et immobilitatem ut
supra dictum est.

Ad primam contra secundam conclusionem, negatur consequentia ut prius, et ad probationem dicitur quod aliquid esse ubi prius non erat potest dupliciter fieri. Primo modo per adventum illius rei ad locum praeexistentem. Secundo per novam
positionem
impositionem positionem
rei in esse vel creationem rei quae est locus. Secundo modo, Deus potest fieri praesens noviter loco et desinere esse in loco non per mutationem Dei sed rei quae est locus, et sic patet quod nec Deus proprie recedit a loco nec deservit locum, sed locus deservit Deum quia desinit esse.
Ad replicam, dicitur quod, licet illud corpus non mutetur de loco ad locum, tamen mutatur quia transiit de non esse ad esse simpliciter et hoc sufficit.

Ad secundam replicam dicitur quod Deus non est ibi per corpus nec ratione corporis si notetur aliqua causalitas in corpore respectu Dei, si autem notetur necessarias commune dicitur quod non prius nec posterius est Deum esse ibi quam corpus, licet secundum naturalem intelligentiam prius sit corpus esse et Deum esse quam Deum esse praesentem corpori vel loco.
Pro quo notandum quod in illo spatio imaginatio extra caelum non est ibi vere alibi nisi potentialiter quia possibile est magnitudinem ibi esse in qua esset formaliter aliud et aliud ibi.

Ad primam contra tertiam conclusionem, dicitur quod si intelligatur sine nova
positione
impositione positione
praesenti vel praeterita, tunc secunda pars. Antecedens est neganda si vero intelligatur sine nova positione praesentis corporis existentis. Negatur consequentia et ad probationem dicitur quod si Deus fiat ibi praesens ibi erit aliqua mutatio praesens vel praeterita respectu corporis sed ad probationem secundae partis antecedentis cum dicitur ponat ibi Deus, angelum, etc., dicitur quod solum probat quod Deus potest ibi esse posito extra caelum aliquo ente creato sine illud maneat sine non, sed non sequitur ex hoc quod possit esse nunc extra caelum nullo ente creato ibi posito simul vel prius, licet angelus possit ibi poni immediate a Deo quia mutatio potest fieri circa angelum non circa Deum sicut Deus non potest fieri de non diligente b diligens b sine mutatione ipsius b, et hoc non est imperfectionis in Deo sed perfectionis quia hoc provenit ex immutante Dei propter quam talis transitus contradictionis non potest fieri circa ipsum sine mutatione facta in alio.

Secundo, dicitur quod Deus non dicitur esse extra caelum in spatio imaginabili quia ibi nihil est nec fuit nec erit et frustra poneretur Deum esse per
s
spatium infinitum in quo nihil operatur unquam.
Ad secundam, negatur antecedens quia illud spatium erat purum nihil, ut dictum sed erat Deus in se ipso.

Secundo, dicitur quod Deum agere actu extra caelum non est ponendum nisi ratio vel auctoritas cogat nec eius immensitas hoc exigit sed exigit quod impossibile est esse locum vel rem quacumque extra deum et distantem ab eo quin Deus sit illi praesens secundum essentiam potentiam et intuitionem et hoc habet deus ex se.

Tertio, dicitur quod, licet aliquod ens per Dei potentiam posset esse ubique, tamen illud ens posset abesse alicui loco existenti nec habet ex se quod possit esse ubique praesens sicut Deus qui ex sua immensitate habet quod non possit abesse alicui dum illud habet esse.
Ad tertiam, posset negari consequentia quia sicut Deus non erat actu praesens tempori quia nihil erat sic nec spatio tali quod nihil est.

Ad quartam, dicitur quod Augustinus loquitur contra illos qui imaginatur ab aeterno usque ad initium creationis mundi in finita spatia temporis pertransita, et consequenter quaerit quare Deus in illis temporibus in finitis cessavit et post modum in hoc tempore determinato incepit et quaerit
de illis imaginando extra mundum proportionaliter esse locorum spatia secundum omnem dimensionem circumquaque protensam et secundum hoc quaerit quare mundus conditus est in hac determinata parte illius spatii magis quam in alia, ideo infert contra illos quod habent ponere infinitatem mundorum per idem argumentum quo arguunt infinitatem seu aeternitatem mundi, Augustinus ergo loquatur contra imaginantes spatium actu quantum est realiter receptaculum corporum coexistentibus corporibus secundum suas partes realiter quod tamen secundum rei veritatem nihil est plus quam chimera.

Ad quintam, admittitur primum positum, sed dicitur quod b non est similis ipsi a quia a est verum ens et reale b non.
Secundo
dist
dico quod b non distat ab a quia inter ens et non ens nulla est distantia.
Tertio, dico quod Deus non posset movere mundum de situ in quo est ad illum situm imaginarium ratio quia impossibile est motum fieri acquisitum loci in vacuo seu ad terminum quod non est ens.
Ad rationes in oppositum patet per dicta in conclusionibus solutio.

Et quoniam demonstratum est
Lombardus, Sent., I, d. 37, c. 1, [n. 1]
prima conclusio distinctionis 37: quod Deus incommutabiliter semper in se existens est in omni natura seu essentia praesentialiter potentialiter et essentialiter sine sui diffinitione, etiam omni loco sine circumscriptione, et omni tempore sine mutabilitate, et etiam in sanctis speritibus[?], et in animalibus habitans per gratiam in homine, vero Christus est excellentissime quia in eo plenitudo deitatis inhabitat corporaliter.

Secunda conclusio: quod ubi Deus habitat ibi Deus est, non tamen ubicumque est ibi habitat, nam sicut anima tota simul a?dem omnibus partibus corporis nec est minor in minoribus, tamen in aliis intensius in aliis remissius operatur, ita Deus ubique est sed in sanctis specialiter dicitur esse per gratiam et in eis habitat sicut in templo mali vero et si ibi sit ubi Deus qui nusquam deest, non tamen sunt cum eo ideo dicitur Pater Noster qui est in caelis, id est in sanctis in quibus est specialiori modo, scilicet per gratiam, non autem dicitur ubique.

Tertia conclusio: quod Deus antequam res essent in se erat bene Deus in se est et in rebus, non enim sancti dicuntur domus Dei, ita ut ipsa subtracta cadat Deus, sed dicitur quod Deus in sanctis habitat, ut si ipse discesserit cadant et deficiant.

Quarta conclusio: quod Deus est habitator quorumdam non cognoscentium Deum, sicut parvulorum per baptismum renatorum et habitator quorumdam cognoscentium Deum, sicut beatorum Deum diligentium quorumdam aut cognoscentium non est habitator, sicut malorum qui eum cognoscunt sed non diligunt, illi enim ad templum Dei non pertinent qui Deum cognoscentes non sicut Deum glorificant.
Quinta conclusio: sicut radii solis non contaminantur sordibus ita divina essentia ubique existens nullis sordibus maculatur.

Sexta conclusio: quod omne corpus est locale et divisive in loco et mobile secundum locum et secundum tempus spiritus vero creatus localis est, sed non divisive, sed determinative, nam ita est hic quod non alibi invenitur et movetur secundum locum et secundum tempus quoniam suscepit vicissitudinem gaudii doloris scientiae et oblivionis, Deus autem in localis est et incircumscriptabilis ubique totus existens quia nec secundum tempus nec secundum locum movetur, sed est omnino immobilis.
